importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest developments in international diplomacy surrounding the Ukraine conflict, particularly involving European leaders, US President Donald Trump, and Russian officials.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current time frame reflects the ongoing and evolving diplomatic efforts between major global powers, especially in the context of ceasefire negotiations and potential Trump-Putin talks.

keyTakeAways: European leaders, including UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, support Trump's call for a ceasefire at the current front line.
Russia dismisses the idea of freezing the front line, insisting on long-term, sustainable peace and full withdrawal of Ukrainian forces from Donbas.
Trump has expressed support for a ceasefire at the current battle line, stating 'cut and stop at the battle line,' but has denied pushing Zelensky to surrender Donbas territory.
Zelensky maintains that Ukraine will not give up control of Donbas, warning Russia could use it as a springboard for future attacks.
The Kremlin continues to demand recognition of Russian sovereignty over Donbas and demilitarisation of Ukraine — demands considered unacceptable by Ukraine and its allies.
A potential Trump-Putin summit in Budapest is being discussed, but requires EU countries to allow Russian air access, creating diplomatic hurdles due to international arrest warrants.
Poland and Lithuania have signaled they would enforce an international arrest warrant for Putin if he enters their airspace; Bulgaria may allow passage through its airspace.
Trump previously proposed a bilateral summit with Zelensky, which was abandoned due to Russia's insistence on addressing root causes of the war.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky is central to the negotiation dynamics, as he opposes any withdrawal from Donbas, emphasizing Ukraine’s territorial integrity and security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Starmer represents the collective European stance in supporting a ceasefire at the current front line, reinforcing Western unity in opposing Russia’s demands.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump has publicly advocated for a ceasefire at the current front line and has proposed direct talks with Putin, making him a pivotal figure in the peace process and a source of international diplomatic tension.

namedEntities.name: Sergei Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is the primary Russian voice rejecting a front-line freeze, advocating instead for maximalist peace terms that include Russian control over Donbas and demilitarisation of Ukraine.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov reiterates Russia’s firm stance on not accepting a front-line freeze, emphasizing the need to address 'root causes' of the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio is set to meet with Lavrov to organize potential Trump-Putin talks, highlighting U.S. diplomatic coordination in the peace negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Donbas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Geographic region in eastern Ukraine (Donetsk and Luhansk)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The contested Donbas region is central to the conflict, with both sides claiming control and Ukraine refusing to surrender territory as part of a peace deal.

namedEntities.name: Budapest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Proposed location for a direct Trump-Putin summit, making it a key diplomatic venue with logistical and political challenges due to airspace restrictions.

namedEntities.name: Poland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Poland has signaled it would enforce an international arrest warrant for Putin if he enters its airspace, showing strong resistance to Russian political presence.

namedEntities.name: Lithuania
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lithuania has similarly committed to executing an arrest warrant for Putin if he travels through its territory, demonstrating regional opposition to Russian state visits.

namedEntities.name: Bulgaria
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bulgaria may allow Putin to transit through its airspace, offering a potential alternative route for the Trump-Putin summit in Budapest.

namedEntities.name: Alaska
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Location of Trump and Putin’s previous summit in August, which failed to produce meaningful results and set a precedent for future diplomatic efforts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: European leaders, including UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, have backed US President Donald Trump's proposal for a ceasefire at the current front line in Ukraine, urging a halt to fighting and negotiations from that line. However, Russia, through Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and spokesperson Dmitry Peskov, rejects this idea, insisting that any peace must address the 'root causes' of the war — including full Russian sovereignty over Donbas and Ukraine's demilitarisation — which Kyiv and its allies view as unacceptable. While Trump has publicly supported a ceasefire at the battle line and stated that the conflict should 'stop at the battle line,' he has denied pushing Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to surrender Donbas. Zelensky maintains that Ukraine will not give up territory, warning it could be used for future attacks. A potential direct Trump-Putin summit in Budapest is being considered, but faces logistical and political hurdles, especially due to international arrest warrants against Putin and the refusal of Poland and Lithuania to allow his plane through their airspace. Bulgaria has offered a possible transit route, highlighting the complex diplomatic and geopolitical tensions shaping the current peace negotiations.
title: Europe's leaders back Trump call for frontline freeze but Russia says no
